episode: EP-64 Behind the Tech Kevin Scott Podcast with Mike Volpi
text:
MIKE VOLPI: First of all I’m okay being wrong. And by the way, I’m wrong all the time, so having compassion for yourself for being mistaken at times, but also continuing to have the self–confidence to say, I believe in my own logic, I believe that this is going to happen, and that allows you to take certain chances.


KEVIN SCOTT: Hi, everyone. Welcome to Behind the Tech. I’m Kevin Scott, Chief Technology Officer and EVP of AI at Microsoft.  
Today, tech is part of nearly every aspect of our lives. We’re in the early days of an AI revolution promising to transform our lived experiences as much as any technology ever has. On this podcast, we’ll talk with the folks behind that technology and explore the motivations, passion, and curiosity driving them to create the tech shaping our world. Let’s get started.
[MUSIC]
CHRISTINA WARREN: Hello and welcome to Behind the Tech. I’m co–host Christina Warren, senior developer advocate at GitHub. 

KEVIN SCOTT: And I’m Kevin Scott.

CHRISTINA WARREN: And today, we are bringing you an interview with Mike Volpi, who is an investor and tech leader. And he’s been a part of nine successful IPOs, including Confluence, Elastic, Aurora, Sonos, Slack, Pure, Zorah, Arista and Hortonworks. Wow, that’s a mouthful! Incredible background.

KEVIN SCOTT: Yeah, that’s a lot of cool stuff.

CHRISTINA WARREN: No, I’m super looking forward to this conversation because, you know, we rarely talk to people, or at least I rarely talk to people. You talk to people like this all the time. I rarely have an opportunity to, you know, hear from people who have this level of experience and investment in tech.

KEVIN SCOTT: Yeah, I mean, Mike is super interesting, you know, in that he had such a long career at Cisco when Cisco was really at the center of the tech world. I mean, Cisco is still like an extremely important company, but, you know, it’s just hard to overstate how important and central Cisco was as we were going through the internet boom, where, you know, in a very, very, very short period of time, you had to figure out how to birth the modern internet, to get everybody in the world connected to it and to get every business that already existed, a presence on the web, and then to build all of the new businesses that the web created the opportunity for. 

And so, Cisco at one point in time was just a fundamental part of the story that you were telling on all of those things. And like, Mike was just dead center of all of that at Cisco for years. 

And I think it’s, you know, particularly interesting thinking about how that internet boom and like, this massive infrastructure buildout, and like this massive scramble to go create a whole bunch of things that never could have existed before back then, parallels what’s going on right now in AI. And like I think him as one of the most successful investors in AI, you know, is no accident. So I’m just super looking forward to this conversation with Mike.

CHRISTINA WARREN: I am, too. Let’s get into it.

[MUSIC]

KEVIN SCOTT: Mike Volpi is a partner at Index Ventures, a venture capital firm. He co–founded the firm’s San Francisco office and North American operations, and he invests primarily in artificial intelligence, infrastructure and open source companies. He spent over a decade at Cisco Systems, where he led acquisitions and built a strategy for mergers and acquisitions that’s used as a model throughout the tech world. 

Mike studied engineering at Stanford, where he earned B.S. in mechanical engineering, an MS in manufacturing systems, and an MBA. He serves on multiple boards, including Aurora, Confluent and Sonos, and he’s a non–executive director on the board of Ferrari. 

Mike, thank you so much for joining us on the podcast today.

MIKE VOLPI: It’s so great to be here, Kevin. Thanks for having me as a guest.

KEVIN SCOTT: Yeah. So you and I have known each other for a while.

MIKE VOLPI: Indeed.

KEVIN SCOTT: So I have been especially looking forward to chatting with you today. Let’s just start with how you got interested in science and technology in general because you – you had a really interesting childhood and upbringing.

MIKE VOLPI: Yeah, I had a little bit of a different, let’s say just different upbringing than most people. So I was born, I like to say, a regular Italian kid, in Milan, Italy. My parents are both from there. And I lived the first six years of my life there in Milan or the area around Milan. 

And then my dad got transferred to Tokyo. He worked for a bank, and they transferred him as an expat over to Tokyo. And then I spent the next 12 years, almost, 11.5 years in Japan, so from basically first grade all the way through high school, I went to American schools there, which is principally why I sound so American and not so Italian, disappointingly to my wife, of course. 

But the interest in engineering, I think, originally came from cars. I loved cars. I mean I remember as a little kid, walls plastered with posters of Ferraris and Lamborghinis and Lancias and all that. And, you know, Italy’s sort of the Mecca for the supercar, sports car, hyper–car thing. 

And you know, it sort of started off with the idea of, you know, wanting to understand how those things worked and what the specs were, and, you know, what a cylinder and an engine was and all of those things. 

So that really the origin of it was there. I don’t even know that I really appreciated it was engineering. 

KEVIN SCOTT: Yeah.

MIKE VOLPI: It was just like a passion for these mechanical things that did amazing stuff and raced. 

So that and I mean, my dad when I was young, took me to Formula One races, which I thought was the coolest thing on earth. I went to Monza with him. I think, you know, he carried me around on his shoulder so I could see. Those are probably my first memories.

KEVIN SCOTT: You know, it’s really interesting, though, because a lot of kids, I think, like particularly in Europe, watch Formula One, you know, with their amily or with their friends. And, you know, it’s not unusual for Formula One fans to look at the driver and say, “Hey, I want to be the driver.” Like, do you understand what it was that made you look at Formula One and say, “Hey, I want to actually be able to make this thing?”

MIKE VOLPI: I think it was, I mean, I didn’t dislike the drivers, but the Formula One cars I thought looked cool, right? They looked amazing. But they – I don’t think that people meant for them to look amazing. They just meant for them to look fast. And the fast would turn into amazing, right? Like it was form followed function in some sense. And I was sort of fascinated, like, I would like, design cars in the evening, like in my notebooks and stuff to make things look cool. 

And actually, there is something about in that era, because today when you think about how cars are designed, it’s real engineering. It’s wind tunnels and drag systems and simulations and all that. But back then it was the idea of looking fast was in the mind of a designer, of an engineer. 

And I think those ideas, and then, you know, the fact that in the end, the fastest cars had the best engine. And so, I wanted to understand, like, you know, if you didn’t have that engine, you weren’t going to win. And so, it’s the technology that’s actually making these people win, and that’s what got me interested in it.

KEVIN SCOTT: Yeah, that’s super interesting. You know, I’m also, you know, fascinated with, you know, your dad was a banker. What did your mom do?

MIKE VOLPI: My mom’s a journalist.

KEVIN SCOTT: Yeah. So – and like, I don’t mean this in any kind of way, but like, you know, they’re not technical people, like not engineers, right? You know, so like, you know, like super, super highly successful people, but like your family or your immediate family wasn’t a bunch of engineers. 

Like were there any other influences? Like, was it just pervasive culture thing? Like, I know both, you know, Italy and Japan are both amazing engineering countries. Like, particularly when we were growing up, like Japan in particular, was like, you know, this ascendant industrial power. Did any of that influence how you thought about the world?

MIKE VOLPI: Neither of my parents have done anything technical, nor are they particularly good with tech. Apparently my grandfather, who I actually have never met, he passed before I grew up, but he was a chemical engineer, and was quite the engineering mindset. 

I think what happened to me was I like these things. And then as I was going to school, I liked doing math. I liked the science classes. And that sort of self–reinforces, you know. And after a while, you’re like, oh, I’m a person that likes this sort of thing. 

So it wasn’t so much that I was influenced per se, although in fairness, both countries, Japan, Italy, they’re both countries that build a lot of mechanical systems generally. In Japan, I was probably more influenced by the electronics part of the culture because the Italians are not...you know, they don’t have a great history in electronics, but the Japanese do. 

And I remember growing up a little later in life where, you know, the Walkman was the thing to own. It was like the coolest thing. And once again, like I was the kid that would get the Walkman and like, undo the screws and look inside and go like, oh, how do they do this thing? How do they make it? You know, how is it that it’s so small and it does these cool things? And so, you know, I always just enjoyed like the how is something made was something that always just interested me. And it got reinforced probably because of the environments. 

There’s actually – you might have been there, Kevin, but in Tokyo there is an area called Akihabara, where they have an electronics district. And now it’s a little – because the world has become much more software than hardware, but at the time, you know, my mom would take me there, and you could just buy anything you wanted, you know, everything from resistors and capacitors, pre–made circuit boards, you know, oscilloscopes. Like anything you wanted, you could go get there. And I was like, you know, I just loved it. You know, every time my mom would take me there for the weekend, I thought it was the super – she thought it was incredibly boring, but I thought it was super cool. So it just sort of bubbled out of me, I would say. But the environment helped for sure.

KEVIN SCOTT: And so, how did you get from, I guess, high school in Japan to Stanford?

MIKE VOLPI: So my high school was – I went elementary, middle and high school in English. So it was kind of obvious to go to an English speaking place, to go to university. All the way through high school, science and math was my thing. So I wanted to go to a university that had more of an engineering orientation. 

U.S. seemed obvious. It was cool, like the U.S. was where cool things were made like, you know what? You know, the companies that we admired at the time, like I had my first computer that I had at school – it wasn’t my computer, it was the school’s computer, was a Commodore PET. 

KEVIN SCOTT: Yep.

MIKE VOLPI: It was like 64k or whatever it was, and it recorded on a cassette tape when you wanted to – you know, storage was like literally a music cassette tape. And then I got a PC that was an NEC made IBM clone. 

And all these things were American. Like Commodore was America, IBM was America. Like all this cool stuff was happening. So going to America was sort of the obvious choice. 

You know, I applied to a couple of schools on the East Coast, and I applied to a couple schools on the West Coast, and the weather was a lot better on the West Coast. (Laughter.) I went to visit schools in April, and it was like 22 degrees in Cambridge and it was like, beautiful and sunny, like today is, in California. And I was like, okay, I know where I’m going. So that’s what got me out here.

KEVIN SCOTT: Well, and in a world of no bad choices...

MIKE VOLPI: I feel very fortunate. I mean, at the time, I will say, you know, in the modern era where it’s so hard for people to get visas in the U.S. and stuff, because, you know, I wasn’t a U.S. citizen obviously at the time. For me back then, it was actually pretty easy to go through the whole thing, get a visa, get citizenship and all that. I feel for the folks today that don’t have a chance to do that as easily.

KEVIN SCOTT: Yeah, it’s amazing how difficult we’ve made it now. But anyway, that’s a conversation for later maybe.

MIKE VOLPI: That’s a separate topic. 

KEVIN SCOTT: So you get to Stanford. This is in the ‘80s. And it’s a really interesting time in Silicon Valley in general. So how did you – I mean, I sort of understand, like, you’re mostly interested in mechanical – mechanical engineering and making mechanical things. And Mech–E is a good choice because you also get to do, like a little bit of electrical engineering and software and whatnot. 

But what was it like at the time? Like, was there this pull at the time towards computer science and symbolic systems and, you know, all of the software stuff that was happening in Silicon Valley or –

MIKE VOLPI: A bit. I would say early, early days. So for example, my mechanical engineering class had 65 graduating in my year. I think symbolic systems had six and computer science had 25. 

KEVIN SCOTT: I didn’t

MIKE VOLPI: I think now Stanford graduates 400 computer science majors a year. Turns out your good friend Reid was a year behind me. So I was class of ‘88, and he was class of ‘89. So I actually knew Reed there, and he was doing this. When I met him, he’s like, I’m a symbolic systems major. I’m like, what is that? I’ve never heard of that.

KEVIN SCOTT: I didn’t realize you were his senpai though.

MIKE VOLPI: Yeah, exactly. 

But I did mechanical mostly because I thought I’d end up designing cars. And in mechanical at the time, I don’t know what it’s like now, but you did two sequences. You did the – thermodynamics sequence. So that’s basically engine design. And then you did the mechanical design, control systems sequence. So I did both, and I thought – and I interviewed with – actually when I graduated, when I was graduating, with a bunch of car companies, actually.

KEVIN SCOTT: And so, I’m just sort of curious, and like, we’ll get back to the interesting stuff. What was the hardest class in Mech–E at the time? Because, like, I –

MIKE VOLPI: Ah, partial differential equations. The math. The math. Math was definitely the hardest. I mean, I was okay at math, but when we get to, like, partial – PDEs, I was like, okay,this is beyond my skill set. So the math was the hardest, I would say. 

The others were – they were fun. Like, you know, I mean, the nice thing – I think for computer science, it’s even more fun today because when you – when you write software, you get feedback immediately for what you’ve done. Mechanical engineering is not so immediate, but it’s pretty immediate, right? Because we had the PRL or the Product Realization Lab at Stanford. So, you know, you would go in. There’s lathes and mills and CNC machines. And you would, you know, CAD out your system, pop it in, and boom, out comes the thing you built. And the thing you built. I mean, you only made one of them, of course, but you know, you’d get it in a day, which is a pretty cool feedback loop, right? 

And so, there’s – I like that a lot. I like that ability to get quick feedback on what you’re doing. And also, it’s practical because it’s very – you know, when you make physical things, it’s very tangible. You can see them and feel them. So there was a lot of reinforcement, positive reinforcement in that major. 

KEVIN SCOTT: Yeah, you know, I kind of feel like an old man dispensing advice, but  I think other than actually making things being fun, I think it’s necessary. If the reason that you’re studying engineering is because you want to make things exist in the world that never existed before, you want to, like, create some effects, like you actually have to do stuff at some point. And the quicker you can start doing stuff where you are actually making the things that you’re trying to understand theoretically. Like, the quicker you learn and the better your career is going to be. 

And it always struck me as weird because like, when I was learning computer science right around the same time, it was really a fashionable thing to teach computer science in a way where your fingers didn’t touch the keyboard. So it was like a bunch of analysis.

MIKE VOLPI: Yes, the theory of computer science.

KEVIN SCOTT: Yeah. And so, it’s interesting, but, like, it’s just not the same as actually doing a thing.

MIKE VOLPI: Yeah. No, I totally agree. I think that, you know, that feedback loop of making something that does, you know, responds then to some behavior that you exhibit, is for a lot of people, it’s super powerful. You can do a lot of theories of things and understand why they work. But that feedback loop to me is super fun. 

And I think the other thing that I find that, you know, I graduated with a mechanical engineering degree. I worked as a mechanical engineer for years, but I’ve not really been a mechanical engineer for a long time. 

However, the methodology of saying, like, I want a thing to end up doing this for me, in order for it to do this for me, I have to break it into a composite set of parts, and then I have to take each part apart and build and, you know, successively build it so that it plugs in together and then becomes that.

That mindset of parsing problems, which is of really the engineering mindset, I think it’s extraordinarily helpful everywhere. I mean, I find that it’s helpful in business and thinking about how to achieve business goals and so forth. 

So foundationally, I mean, obviously it’d be great if we graduated more engineers in the world because I think we can always use more. But even if you end up doing something else in life, I still think it’s an unbelievable foundation for somebody to start with.

KEVIN SCOTT: And were you – so we’ve already talked about you being sort of a curious kid. So you were, like taking things apart to try to understand how they work. Then, you know, you’re just like, drawn to complexity, not daunted by it. But were you also a skeptical kid?

MIKE VOLPI: Let’s see. I wouldn’t say that I was extraordinarily skeptical. I mean, I think. I didn’t like it when people BS’d about things, when people made up stuff that I couldn’t then sum up in my own mind, right? If you say like, it’s X and then you go like, well, how is X composed, and that doesn’t really kind of make sense, I didn’t like that very much. But I was aspirational, as in like I always felt drawn to the idea of creating something that doesn’t exist today. 

So in that sense, I did have some skepticism, but I was more motivated by what’s around the corner, what’s next, what’s cool and how can it be practical, right, how can it be useful day one? 

And I’m sure we’ll get to some conversation about AI, but there’s also distinction there about like, oh, well, it’s this amazing thing over there. But I always try to think about, you know, how is this practical for me today as opposed to just pure vision? Like, I like aspirational, but I like it to the extent that I can practically apply it to what I do today.

KEVIN SCOTT: Yeah, which I think is – it’s a good impulse. 

So you graduate Stanford, and then you go get a job as a mechanical engineer. What – what was – what was that job? What were you doing?

MIKE VOLPI: I was a product designer, a product design engineer for HP in the optoelectronics division. So we made – HP at the time made various things that used gallium arsenide semiconductor material to create light. And, you know, you make a lot of products that create light. That can be everything from displays to automotive components to fiber optic connectors to all sorts of things. But I was an engineer in the group there. 

KEVIN SCOTT: And what did that look like? Because I think when people hear things like that, like depending on what your background is, you summon up a bunch of different images, you know, were you’re sitting at a desk all day, doing schematics and drawings. Were you in a lab tinkering around with stuff? Were you with customers, like helping them build things?

MIKE VOLPI: No, I was pretty much – so a mechanical engineer’s principal tool are CAD/CAM. So HP had its in–house CAD/CAM system. I got – grew up on AutoCAD and CATIA, which were the kind of industry standards, but HP didn’t use those. So I was on ME10, ME30, which at the time ran on workstations, big computers that with your desk, you design this thing. It’s a three dimensional renderer that you did stuff and you like designed it in various shapes and forms. 

And then typically, you would design one out, you would send it out to the prototyping shop, they would make it, then you would test it. So you would take it into a lab. And you know, in my case it had to have certain thermal characteristics. 

So it was an interesting job because it involved both thermal – well, when semiconductors are pounded hard with electricity, they create heat. And when you create heat, the performance degrades, and also it creates – if you involve it with plastic, it melts plastic around it. 

So I had to do a lot of thermal stuff to make sure that we weren’t overheating these systems, and then mechanical design to make them fit into certain mechanical spaces was what I was doing.

They would – I would design it. The prototype shop would build it up. We would test it. And then when it was tested enough to our satisfaction, we would send it over to what was called New Product Introduction Engineering, NPIE. Those were the guys that basically took our designs and turned them into a production line that they would make them. 

At the time, our products were made in Malaysia, so we had a bunch of NPIEs over in Malaysia that would take our product design and then put them in and try to build them. And, you know, usually you made something and it didn’t work. So then you had to go, you know, spin it another time and do it right. 

But it was probably – yeah I mean, it’s a long time ago, but I’d say 30% of the time, CAD/CAM 30% of the time working with other people to, you know, facilitate, and a bunch of time testing, and test eval was a lot of time. And we had to run a lot of tests that ran long periods of time, and then we had to do temperature chambers to cycle them and those sorts of things. So that was basically the job.

KEVIN SCOTT: Interesting. And so, at some point, you made the shift from being a mechanical engineer at a Silicon Valley company to like being more actively involved in software. Like, how did that happen?

MIKE VOLPI: Well, I always did a bit of – so I was programing in BASIC in high school. I programed a little bit in Fortran also in high school. I took a bunch of Pascal classes in college. So it was, you know, it was sort of there. 

It’s funny, I was talking to my – my dad’s always been a good advisor, mentor to me. And he – mechanical engineering, he can understand. But when I was like, well, because when I was thinking of majors, I was like, ME, maybe CS. I asked my dad and he’s like, “Computer science, that’s like games and stuff. You don’t want to do that. That’s a really bad career path. Stick with mechanical engineering. Way better.” It’s like, thanks for the advice, dad, really appreciate it.

KEVIN SCOTT: It worked out for you.

MIKE VOLPI: I could have been – you know, if he hadn’t given me the advice, I could be CTO at Microsoft right now.

KEVIN SCOTT: Yeah, you made the right choices, my friend. (Laughter.) 

MIKE VOLPI: But yeah. So I always played around with software. But what actually happened is my boss at HP had an MBA. He was the manager of the engineering group that I was working in. And, you know, he  liked me a lot and was very kind to me. And he, you know, he was like, you know, for an engineer, you ask a lot of why questions, like why are we doing this? This product doesn’t seem to make sense. Why? You know, what’s the – you know, why are we making this one instead of that one? And why is that division over there? So he said, you should really go and explore the business world to kind of understand, and you should get an MBA. 

So my third year, at three years of engineering, I applied to business schools, and I decided to leave and go to – my manager actually wrote my letter of recommendation, and I had decided to go to business school to sort of understand the business likes of it, not knowing what I would do afterwards. I assumed maybe I’d go back to doing what I was doing before, but I’d learn it. 

And I think that’s where sometimes in your career you get lucky because doors open. But in my second year of business school, I was organizing a conference, a technology conference for the business school at Stanford. We were inviting these speakers to do things. 

And originally back then, this is circa 1990 – early 1994, when you advertised the conference, you would put posters up around campus, say, you know, come by, we have these speakers, whatever. 

And one of my friends was like, well, we shouldn’t do posters, we should do a website. And I was like, what’s a website? And they’re like, oh, there’s this thing called the web. And I was like, oh, like the thing that you do email on? Because we had email. I even had email at work back then, but the web wasn’t a thing. 

And in early ‘94, what was then Mosaic and then eventually became Netscape had launched the web server, web browser. And so, instead of making posters, we made a website, and we would have – we had a very simple little database where you could enter your email, and then we would then follow up with an invitation on email. 

And, you know, it got me to exploring the internet and that, you know, the light bulb went off. You know, seeing the web, I was like, wow, like, this is – nobody’s ever going to make posters anymore. It was one of those luminary moments. 

But no, I sort of got the bug. And then I actually said, like, whatever I’m doing, I have to find a job that has to do with the web, like, doesn’t matter what. And at the time, ‘94, eBay was started in ‘95, Yahoo was started in ‘95. There literally weren’t – there were no internet companies in ‘94. 

And so, then typical engineering mindset, and I was like, well, if there’s no like web companies, like, how’s the internet made? And I started doing research on how the internet works. And there’s this thing called TCP/IP, and there’s routers and switches. I was like, well, who makes those? There’s a company called Cisco makes them. 

So I like I cold called the CEO. I just like – and at the time, you actually called people, literally cold call people. And his assistant was nice enough to put me through, and I chatted with him for a bit.

KEVIN SCOTT: And this was – this was [John] Chambers at the time?

MIKE VOLPI: No, this was still the first CEO was a guy called John Morgridge. John was nice enough to, like, literally take my call. And he invited me down, and I did a few interviews and got passed around. And finally the guy, the CTO, actually, of the company hired me to be his sort of technical assistant basically. It’s like you come and do whatever I tell you to do.

And then one thing led to another, but it was literally like that conference and making a website. Like I just, you know, we got on – my friend and I got on, made some HTML stuff, and I was just like, hooked.

KEVIN SCOTT: What did that job look like at Cisco? So like you were the TA to the CTO. Like, what were some of the technical problems that you all were trying to sort out? You know, this is what, ‘95?

MIKE VOLPI: Yeah. So well, really ‘94, ‘95. So the first context, Cisco was a small company then. It was about 2,000 employees. It was very informal. We had grown up very, very fast. The company was a couple hundred million in revenue, I want to say. And so, roles were a lot less formal than roles are today in the organization. 

They basically hired me because there were two technological themes that could affect their core business. They had routing, and they had two technological themes. One was broadband to the home, right, because back then, it was all dial-up. And so, they wanted to evaluate broadband technologies. And then the other one was that the – there’s a technology that sits right next to routing called switching, which is sort of a more hardware-oriented approach to moving packets on the internet, which they were afraid would disrupt routers. Turns out to be true; it did. But they were worried that that technology could obsolete routers. And we had to evaluate from a business development perspective whether we should be making acquisitions in that sector. 

So those are the two projects I got a chance to work on with the CTO. The broadband work led to essentially us partnering and investing with a few of the cable companies to make cable modems. So they were invented at Cisco. And then on the switching side, we ended up acquiring a bunch of companies, like four of them, including Andy Bechtolsheim’s company at the time, to build the entire switching product line at Cisco via acquisition. And that turned out to eventually become the largest part of Cisco.

KEVIN SCOTT: That’s kind of incredible that you were there helping to sort all of this stuff out strategically, right as the internet was beginning to take off.

MIKE VOLPI: Yeah, well, I think what was, what I learned to really appreciate at the time was my boss at the time, the CTO, was very good at sort of seeing, okay, this is what we’re doing today. It’s great. Business is humming. We love it. But there are things that might happen two years from now that will dramatically disrupt what we’re doing. And all this happy stuff that’s happening now will finish in three years if we don’t pay attention to that next thing. Right? And that, you know, the natural tendency of a business that’s going well is to just keep doing what it’s doing. And he was very good at saying, like uh-uh, like that’s the exact moment that you have to go and lean in to the thing that might kill you. 

And I think I was mostly there helping, because he was a big strategic thinker, but was not very good, not very hands on. And so, I was like hands for him. So he would say like, okay, go explore that one, go do this, talk to this guy over here. 

And in the process of doing the work for him, osmosis set in. And I was like, oh, that’s how I got to look at the world of business, and that’s how it works. And it’s like being an engineer, and you’re like sort of sitting there saying, oh, if only we did it this way, this can create another opportunity over here, right? That was the biggest lesson for me at the time.

KEVIN SCOTT: And so, you were at Cisco actually for quite a long while. So 10 years, as far as Silicon Valley, 10 years ago is, I mean, that’s a long tenure. I mean, by Microsoft standards, like people stay here for, like, we just –

MIKE VOLPI: No, it was even longer. 

MIKE VOLPI: Oh, was it?

MIKE VOLPI: So it was 14 years I was there. 

KEVIN SCOTT: Yes.

MIKE VOLPI: Yeah.

KEVIN SCOTT: So well, I guess two questions then. So like one, like what made you stay so long when I’m sure every month there was some new opportunity? Like you had this great career. You were probably getting called all the time to come do other things. Like you could have stopped being at Cisco at any point. Like, what was the thing that kept you there for as long as you did? 

And then I’d love to understand, like, you know, when you finally did decide to move on, like, why did you choose what came next?
